thread.title: Stopping Louisville quarterback Lamar Jackson an 'extreme challenge' for Florida State, coach Jimbo Fisher says
thread.title_full: Stopping Louisville quarterback Lamar Jackson an 'extreme challenge' for Florida State, coach Jimbo Fisher says

author: courier-journal.com
title: Stopping Louisville quarterback Lamar Jackson an 'extreme challenge' for Florida State, coach Jimbo Fisher says
text:
Jimbo Fisher says Lamar Jackson has kept him up at night.
The Florida State coach, whose team has run through 27 consecutive Atlantic Coast Conference opponents, said Monday that he’d been watching film of Louisville’s speedy freshman quarterback and wondering how the No. 11 Seminoles will contain him Saturday in Tallahassee.
“I didn't sleep much the night before,” Fisher said. “He gave me a headache. That guy can throw. He can run.”
After running for 435 yards in five games, Jackson has established himself as the Cardinals’ most potent weapon on offense. He has already set U of L’s single-season record for rushing by a quarterback, and he’s No. 4 nationally in rushing among QBs and No. 3 among all freshmen.
His ability to run the ball – or Florida State’s ability to thwart his efforts – will probably be a big factor in determining the outcome of Saturday’s game at Doak Campbell Stadium.
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
U of L freshman seeing progress on blind side
As Jackson's 68-yard touchdown run two weeks ago against NC State indicated, he is one of Louisville’s fastest players at any position. FSU defensive end DeMarcus Walker said Jackson is probably the biggest running threat of all the QBs he’s had to face. And that’s a group that includes Oregon's Heisman Trophy winner and No. 2 NFL draft pick Marcus Mariota.
“Oh, he’s probably the biggest threat of a QB I saw, over Mariota,” Walker said, according to the Orlando Sentinel . “He’s faster than Mariota. He has a pretty good arm, too. I was watching him, like good God … the kid can fly.”
Fisher recruited Jackson out of Boynton Beach (Fla.) High School and said he has always held him in high regard. Fisher said he respects Jackson’s speed and running ability but thinks Jackson is dangerous as a passer, too.
Fisher mentioned the quarterback as one of several talented players on a Louisville team that he believes could just as easily be 5-0 as 2-3.
“He is a runner, and he is dynamic, but at the same time he has great arm strength,” the FSU coach said. “He can make throws all over the field and make plays and keeps play alive. It is going to be an extreme challenge for us to make sure we can try and contain him, and I don't know if you ever really can. But you have to try to limit his opportunities.”
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
FSU's Fisher: Cards could be 5-0
Jackson’s passing numbers have been fairly pedestrian so far: 52-of-97 for three touchdowns with four interceptions. He was just 10-of-27 for 103 yards and a TD – but with no turnovers – in rainy conditions at NC State.
Louisville spent much of its off week on fundamental work, and offensive coordinator Garrick McGee said he could see improvement from Jackson in his passing technique.
Wide receiver James Quick said Jackson is getting better with each additional week studying the playbook.
“What he's doing a better job of now is in his preparation and really understanding the grind that you have to go through and the work you have to put in,” Cards coach Bobby Petrino said, "being able to take care of the football and make decisions based off what you see the secondary do and the coverages. I've been impressed with his improvement on his reads and distributing the ball. He needs to continue to get better on his footwork and be in balance so that he's more accurate throwing it.”
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
New CardsHQ podcast: On FSU and the UofL book
McGee said the Cards have tended to play Jackson mostly from the shotgun because he’s comfortable in that formation, but the coach said Jackson is also capable of playing under center. That could be important as Louisville seeks to have more success from a traditional power-running game in which the ball is handed off to the running backs.
“(Jackson) understands how to do it,” McGee said.
But Jackson’s own runs have so far presented the biggest threat for opponents. Fisher said the challenge of facing a mobile quarterback like Jackson is defending the edges of the line of scrimmage once the QB starts to dash outside.
Florida State’s defense, which surrendered just 20 rushing yards in a win over Miami last week and is ranked No. 25 nationally against the run, shapes up as one of the faster groups the Cards will have faced. McGee and Petrino mentioned that the Seminoles boost their speed by playing five or more defensive backs at once.
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
Practice Report | Off week helps young Cards
So is Jackson fast enough to get around the corner against the speedy Seminoles?
“Yeah,” McGee said. “Lamar is a pretty fast guy.”
FSU linebacker Jacob Pugh called Jackson “unbelievable” and said FSU’s coaches spent the weekend prepping for him and emphasizing to the players that he’ll be a lot to handle.
“He’s real fast,” Pugh said. “He’s a freshman, and he’s real fresh. He’s real smart. We just have to watch him and can’t let him get outside of us.”
How will the Noles contain the U of L QB?
“For one, we’ve got a lot of speed. So we can match his speed,” Pugh said. “That ain’t nothing to us.”
Steve Jones can be reached at (502) 582-7176 and followed on Twitter at @SteveJones_CJ.
